column1: Rēzekne (Latgalian Rēzekne pronounced [ˈrʲæːzʲækʲnʲæ] or Rēzne pronounced [rʲæːzʲnʲæ]
column2: Latvian: Rēzekne pronounced [ˈrɛːzekne] (listen); see other names) is a city in the Rēzekne River valley in Latgale region of eastern Latvia. It is called The Heart of Latgale (Latvian Latgales sirds
column3: Latgalian Latgolys sirds). Built on seven hills
column4: Rēzekne is situated 242 kilometres (150 miles) east of Riga
column5: and 63 kilometres (39 miles) west of the Latvian-Russian border

column1: == Other names ==
In Latgalian name of the city is Rēzne pronounced [rʲæːzʲnʲæ] or Rēzekne pronounced [ˈrʲæːzʲækʲnʲæ].
Rēzekne was historically known as Rositten in German.

A Russian name from the time of the Russian Empire was Рѣжица (Rezhitsa) although Резекне pronounced [ˈrɛzɛknɛ] is now used. Some other names for the city include: Polish: Rzeżyca and Yiddish: רעזשיצע‎ Reżice.
== History ==
A Latgalian hill fort is known to have existed at Rēzekne from the 9th to the 13th centuries
column2: until its destruction at the hands of German crusaders of the Livonian Order. In 1285
column3: the knights built a stone fortress on the site
column4: which is today known as Rēzekne castle ruins
column5: to serve as a border post on their eastern frontier.

column1: The name Rēzekne was first documented in 1285. Throughout its early history
column2: Rēzekne was attacked many times by Russian and Lithuanian forces. The town became part of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth after the Peace of Jam Zapolski in 1582 during the Livonian War. Rēzekne received Magdeburg rights from Poland in the 17th century
column3: but fell to the Russian Empire during the Partitions of Poland. In 1773
column4: Rēzekne received city rights. Known as "Rezhitsa" during Russian rule
column5: it was an uyezd center first in Pskov Governorate between 1772 and 1776
column7: Belarus between 1796 and 1802 and finally in Vitebsk Governorate between 1802 and 1917.

column1: During the 19th century
column2: the construction of the Moscow-Ventspils and Saint Petersburg-Warsaw railways transformed Rēzekne from a sleepy country town into an important city with two stations.

column1: In the spring of 1917
column2: the first Latgalian congress was held in Rēzekne
column3: in which Latgale was declared to unite with the other Latvian regions. Following Latvia's declaration of independence in 1918
column4: the Latvian War of Independence and the driving out of both the German and Red armies from Latvia
column5: the city became a cultural centre for all of Latgale.

column1: Rēzekne was heavily damaged by both Nazi and Soviet armies during World War II. It was captured by troops of the German Army Group North on 4 July 1941 and placed under the administration of the newly created Reichskommissariat Ostland on 25 July 1941. Rēzekne was recaptured by troops of the Soviet 2nd Belorussian Front on 27 July 1944. Due to the heavy air-bombing by Soviet forces in 1944
column2: ⅔ of its buildings were destroyed. Out of a pre-war population of 13
column4: only 5
column5: 000 people remained in the city at the end of the war.

column1: Rēzekne was rebuilt after the war with an emphasis on industrial development. Rēzekne had the 5th highest industrial output in the Latvian SSR
column2: including a dairy processor (Rēzeknes Piena konservu kombināts)
column3: a lumber mill
column4: and an electric-instrument factory (Rebir). During this time
column5: many Russians moved to the city
column6: making up a large part of the population (48.5% in 2007).

column1: == Religion ==
Due to Rēzekne's multi-ethnic character throughout the centuries
column2: many religious communities have settled in the city. Ethnic differences were often distinguished on religious lines; the Germans brought Christianity to Latvia in the 13th century
column3: as well as Lutheranism during the Reformation Period. The Polish influence over Latgalia in the 17th and 18th centuries strengthened Catholicism among the native Latgalians. Incoming populations of Russian Old Believers introduced Russian Orthodoxy
column4: and up to the 1940s
column5: Rēzekne had a very large Jewish population

column1: === Sacred Heart Cathedral ===
The Catholic Cathedral "Vissvētā Jēzus Sirds" (Sacred Heart of Jesus)
column2: (built 1893-1914) dominates Rēzekne's skyline looking from the castle hill.

column1: The Cathedral was consecrated in 1901. It was built on the site of a previous wooden church which had been constructed from the funds allotted by Kraków military leader Belinski. In 1887 the church was destroyed in a thunderstorm-caused fire.
The cathedral has curved wooden altars decorated by the sculptures of Jesus Christ
column2: Virgin Mary
column3: St.Teresa
column4: and others. The cathedral is famous for its depictions in stained glass of the first Livonian bishops
column5: Saint Meinhard and Albert of Riga. Since 1995 it has been the centre of the Rezekne-Aglona diocese with the seat of the bishop.

column1: The church has an active choir whose members have studied music. A majority of the members work as musicians and enjoy their Sunday singing in the church.
=== Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church ===
The other Catholic church
column2: "Sāpju Dievmāte" (Our Lady of Sorrows) is much newer
column3: built from 1935–1939.

column1: Construction began in 1936. The 27 metres (89 feet) tall building was built in neo-romantic style. The church was consecrated on 6 December 1937
column2: but the construction was finished only in 1939. Next to the church is a sculpture of Our Lady of Fátima.

column1: Like many 1930s buildings in the city such as the Nation Palace of Latvian Society (the House of Culture nowadays)

column1: === Orthodox Church of the Birth of Holy Jesus' Mother ===
Construction of the church dates back to 1840
column2: though it wasn't consecrated until 1846. In 1854 it was closed for reconstruction. After a two-year reconstruction period the church obtained its definitive look.

column1: Tile stoves
column2: tiled floors
column3: three-storey iconostasis and a granite stoop decorated the church. A small stone chapel in memory of Alexander II's rescue from death is situated on the left side of the church entrance. On the right there is a glass burial vault where the founder of the church

column1: === Evangelical Lutheran Holy Trinity Church ===

The red brick church from was built in the 1930s. The church was designed by the architect J.Cīrulis in Neo-Gothic style. The church was consecrated in 1938. In the summer of 1949 the Soviet authority deprived the parishioners of their church
column2: removed its crosses and dismantled the belfry. For many years there was a film rental company.The parish got back its property at the beginning of the 1990s and the building has undergone major repairs. It is possible to climb the 37 metres (121 feet) bell tower and see Rēzekne from above. Classical music concerts and divine services take place in the church nowadays.

column1: === St.Nicholas Old-Believers' Church ===
The church was built in 1895. In 1906 it was considerably reconstructed

column3: for which the church is now famous. One of them weighs 4

column1: === Green Synagogue ===
Prior to World War II
column2: there were eleven synagogues in Rēzekne. The Green Synagogue is the only one to have survived to this day.

column1: The synagogue was built in 1845 and is considered to be one of the oldest wooden buildings in Rēzekne. The synagogue was open until the 1990s
column2: when it was closed for fire safety reasons.

column1: The State Inspection for Heritage Protection of Latvia added it to the list of the most endangered sites in 2004. The Rezekne City Council with the support of Norwegian Financial Institutions started reconstruction of the building. Within the framework of the project it will be possible to create an exhibition devoted to the history of Rezekne's Jews.
== Culture ==
=== Latgales Māra ===
One of the most famous statues in Latvia
column2: known as "Latgales Māra"
column3: is found in Rēzekne. It was designed by Leons Tomašickis and first unveiled on September 8
column4: 1939. The bronze statue commemorates the liberation of Latgale from the Red Army in January 1920.

column1: The central figure
column2: the woman
column3: is popularly associated with Māra the ancient Latvian goddess of motherhood
column4: fertility
column5: and earth. The cross in her outstretched arm symbolizes the deep importance of Catholicism to Latgalian culture. The words "Vienoti Latvijai" beneath the statue (meaning "United for Latvia") designates the decision to reunite with the rest of Latvia during the Republic's formation in 1918
column6: even though Latgale had been politically separated from the rest of Latvia for 300 years.

column1: Because the statue symbolized Latvian nationalism
column2: the Soviets toppled it in November 1940 during the first Soviet occupation of Latvia. Under German occupation the local residents restored it on August 22
column3: 1943. The reinstated Soviet government pulled it down again in June 1950. After that
column4: the fate of the original statue is unknown.

column1: After Latvia regained its independence in 1991
column2: the statue was reconstructed using old photographs and blueprints
column3: and unveiled on August 13
column4: 1992. Though Soviet rule greatly changed Latgale
column5: Latgales Māra still symbolizes a Catholic Latgale united with Latvia

column1: === Castle Ruins ===
The Castle Ruins
column2: situated on the hill by the river
column3: are the reminders of the ancient fortified residence of ancient Latgalians which existed there from the 9th to 13th centuries. At the end of the 13th century the Livonian Order built a stone castle (Rozitten castle). It was situated in a strategically important place
column4: so the Russians
column5: Lithuanians and Poles were seeking to conquer it. The castle was completely destroyed during the Polish-Swedish war (1656-1660). A model of Rēzekne castle by Edmunds Smans is located near the castle hill.

column1: === Latgale Culture and History Museum ===
The Latgale Culture and History Museum (Latgales Kultūrvēstures muzejs) was opened in 1959. The museum offers exposition of the town history
column2: art exhibitions
column3: and pedagogical activities for children. The exposition of Latgale ceramics is the only permanent exposition in Latvia to reflect Latgalian ceramics in its history from the beginning of pottery in the Neolithic period until the achievements of present-day Latgalian ceramists and modern developments. At the moment the museum stock collection has about 65 thousand items.

column1: === Art House ===
The building which is now the Art House was built in the last quarter of the 19th century for the merchant Vorobjov. It features rich woodcarvings on its façade
column2: decorated in an eclectic style.

column1: It soon became the property of the city
column2: and was used as a teachers' institute
column3: a school
column4: a tuberculosis centre and a military registration office. This frequent change of users almost totally destroyed the original rich interior.

column1: In the middle of the 1990s it was acquired by the Rezekne Art College. Due to the efforts of the students and teachers
column2: the Art House got back its original outlook. It houses the exposition "Latgalian painting" from the reserves of the Latgale Culture History Museum.

column1: === Eastern Latvia's Center of Creative Services "Zeimuļs" ===
The Eastern Latvia's Center of Creative Services "Zeimuļs" houses classes of interest and non-formal education for children and youth.
The opening of the center was on September 1
column2: 2012. The architects were Rasa Kalniņa and Māris Krumiņš who used Latvian ethnographic motifs in their design. The main construction materials are concrete
column3: glass
column4: metal and wood. It is the largest building with a green roof in the Baltic countries. The towers offer one of the best views in Rezekne
column5: over the Castle Hill and the historical center of the city.
